issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: Currently the 4.0 console uses multiple run requests to run multiple instances rather than using one request using the min/max values.  This is not release critical for 4.0.0.
fields.summary: User Console should launch instances with min/max == number of instances

comments.body:
Yea, that's crazy. Fixing this now!

FWIW, a standard practice is to set min = 1 and max = desired number. So, at least you get some.. setting min = desired number as well results in more failures and manual retries with a lower limit. I'm going to implement that unless I hear objections.
https://github.com/eucalyptus/koala/pull/223

[~dkavanagh]: To add some context here, a prior version of the run_instances call used min/max values (see the git history for views/instances.py), but only the first instance was displaying on the instances landing page since we had a bug in the fetch for that page that only fetched the first instance in a reservation.  That bug was subsequently fixed, but I didn't get around to fixing the run_instances call to revert to using the min/max values rather than the enumerate loop.
[~alice] Feel free to assign this to me if you need help QA'ing this ticket.
When I tried to launch 5 windows instances on my test-cloud, there were not enough resources and instead 3 instances were launched. The expected behavior in this case to have "request denied".
The expected behavior is to launch as many as possible up to the number requested. It worked!

[~dkavanagh] this is the behavior in CLI:

[root@g-08-09 ~]# euca-run-instances emi-524153f1 -t m2.xlarge -n 5
euca-run-instances: error (InsufficientInstanceCapacity): Not enough resources (3 in  < 5): vm instances.

The console instead of matching this behavior is launching 3 instances. 

My understanding, from the ticket was that the two behaviors should match. [~viglesias], could you please comment on this?

There are 2 things that this bug should fix:

1) all instances from one run request should be in the same reservation
2) If the number of instances cannot be launched it should reject the request

For 1 to happen we need to sending multi instance launch requests using the min/max parameters of RunInstance. If 1 is implemented as such 2 is free.

As I commented way above, I designed this to run min=1 and max=<requested #>. Perhaps this may not be clear to a user, but you will get as many instances as possible in an instance constrained environment (as many private clouds are). The only other way to learn how many you may launch is to keep trying different values. [~jloza]?

[~dkavanagh] [~jloza]

I suggest we use min==max in this case so that when you try to launch 5 and fail, you get immediate feedback. I think launching "as many as we can" is weird for the user since there is no notion of minimum presented.

[~viglesias], [~dkavanagh], [~kgill], shouldn't our CLI be behaving in a way that is compatible with AWS? It sounds like in AWS it launches as many as it can, out of the number you requested. 

I would expect:
A) that our CLI and GUI behave in a consistent manner with each other, and
B) that the manner is which we behave is consistent with AWS. 

Do we know why our CLI doesn't behave consistently with AWS, if AWS in fact does launch as many as it can out of the requested number?

[~jloza]

When a min is not provided the max==min on the CLI.

This is a trivial change and I can make it quickly with little risk. I just thought we ought to talk through the pros and cons. no biggie. My experience with setting min = 1 comes from earlier days of EC2 when some zones filled up and you'd get resource error messages. AWS  (at that time) suggested the best way was min=1 and max=desired. Then, retry till you got the number you wanted. That was because it was a big public cloud and resource errors were generally transient. In a sense, we're going to have more resource errors with Euca since private clouds are "generally" smaller. That doesn't mean we should force min=1 (as I was). Since the UI only offers a single number for entry, I'm totally fine going min=max=desired.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/641
I'll merge this once CI tests pass.
Thanks, all.

When I tried to launch 10 instances, only 3 were launched, movie attached. 

Expected behavior would be: 0 instances launched. 

Tested on FF/MAC, console installed from packages on CentOS
I know what the problem is. we don't set min_count specifically, so boto defaults to 1. I'll get a PR ready.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/702

looks like run_instances for launch_more was covered, but not the main run_instances that the launch_instance wizard uses.
Pull request 702 merged
